contentrichtext.text: {{one source|date=February 2012}} {{no footnotes|date=February 2012}} '''Caesius Bassus''' was a [[Roman Empire|Roman]] lyric [[poet]], who lived in the reign of [[Nero]]. He was the intimate friend of [[Aulus Persius Flaccus|Persius]], who dedicated his sixth satire to him, and whose works be edited (''Schol. on Persius'', vi. I). He is said to have lost his life in the eruption of [[Vesuvius]] (79). He had a great reputation as a poet; [[Quintilian]] (''Instit.'' x. I. 96) goes so far as to say that, with the exception of [[Horace]], he was the only lyric poet worth reading. He is also identified with the author of a treatise ''De Metris'', of which considerable fragments, probably of an abbreviated edition, are extant (ed. Keil, 1885). The work was probably originally in verse, and afterwards recast or epitomized in [[prose]] form to be used as an instruction book. An account of some of the metres of Horace (in Keil, ''Grammatici Latini'', vi. 305), bearing the title ''Ars Caesii Bassi de Metris'' is not by him, but chiefly borrowed by its unknown author, from the treatise, mentioned above. ==References== *{{1911}} ==External links== *[http://kaali.linguist.jussieu.fr/CGL/index.jsp Corpus Grammaticorum Latinorum: complete texts and full bibliography] {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Bassus, Caesius | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bassus, Caesius}} [[Category:79 deaths]] [[Category:Latin-language writers]] [[Category:Silver Age Latin writers]] [[Category:Roman-era poets]] [[Category:1st-century poets]] [[Category:Deaths in volcanic eruptions]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] {{ancient-Rome-bio-stub}} {{Euro-writer-stub}}
